summary: William G. Miller appears in several documents related to the Senate Select Committee (SSC) investigations into intelligence activities. He is listed in a memorandum detailing staff personnel with security clearances up to TOP SECRET. He is also mentioned in transcripts of Senate Select Committee hearings, responses to the SSC's requests for information, and FBI memoranda pertaining to the SSC's investigation of intelligence activities. His specific role or involvement is not explicitly detailed in the provided summaries, but his presence across multiple documents suggests he was likely a staff member or involved in the administrative or investigative processes of the Senate Select Committee.
significance: Based on the provided documents, William G. Miller's significance in the JFK assassination context is indirect. He is associated with the Senate Select Committee's broader investigation into intelligence activities, which included examining the FBI's and CIA's actions. While the documents mention investigations related to Martin Luther King Jr. and alleged communist ties, there is no direct mention of the JFK assassination.
